unnormalised: ## My Wallet Weeps: Adventures in Indian Charity (and Saving My Chai Money)
normalised: ## My Wallet Weeps: Adventures in Indian Charity (and Saving My Chai Money)

unnormalised: So, you want to be a philanthropist, huh? A modern-day Karna, raining down rupees like confetti at a Bollywood wedding? Good for you! Me? I'm usually the guy scrambling to find Rs. 5 for the auto-rickshaw driver after a particularly ambitious round of window shopping at Sarojini Nagar. But even *I* occasionally attempt to embrace my inner good samaritan.
normalised: So, you want to be a philanthropist, huh? A modern-day Karna, raining down rupees like confetti at a Bollywood wedding? Good for you! Me? I'm usually the guy scrambling to find rupees five for the auto-rickshaw driver after a particularly ambitious round of window shopping at Sarojini Nagar. But even I occasionally attempt to embrace my inner good samaritan.

unnormalised: The first hurdle, of course, is the relentless bombardment of donation requests. Every traffic light is a gauntlet of hopeful eyes and outstretched hands. My usual tactic? A strategically timed coughing fit. Classy, I know. But hey, Rs. 10 here, Rs. 20 there... it adds up! That's like, two cups of chai at my regular *chaiwala*! And let’s be honest, chai is basically charity, keeping me functioning and vaguely resembling a productive member of society.

unnormalised: Then there's the online world. Ugh. Every click seems to trigger another popup urging me to donate to [insert worthy cause here]. One time, after buying a single packet of Maggi (for the record, it was Rs. 14, thank you very much!), I got bombarded with requests to "Sponsor a Child for Just Rs. 500/Month!". Look, I'm barely sponsoring *myself* at this point. Maggi is my gourmet meal.

unnormalised: And don't even get me started on the family WhatsApp groups. Auntie Sheila is constantly forwarding links for this orphanage or that old age home. “Please donate generously! Even Rs. 100 will make a difference!” she proclaims, complete with at least five crying emojis. Which, frankly, is emotional blackmail. I suspect she knows I’m a softie.

unnormalised: The real challenge, though, is figuring out where your money actually *goes*. I once donated Rs. 1000 to a "Save the Tigers" campaign. Next thing I know, I'm getting spammed with ads for tiger-themed merchandise! A tiger-shaped stress ball? A tiger-striped phone cover? Clearly, *someone’s* definition of “saving the tigers” is… creative.

unnormalised: But jokes aside, I do genuinely want to help. I've started small. I round up my grocery bill to the nearest rupee and donate the change. I've even started carrying a stash of Rs. 5 coins specifically for the aforementioned traffic light gauntlet. Baby steps, people.

unnormalised: So, what have I learned from my limited (and occasionally guilt-ridden) adventures in Indian charity? That it’s a complicated, often overwhelming, and occasionally hilarious journey. And that maybe, just maybe, I can balance my love for cheap chai with my desire to do a little good in the world. Now, if you’ll excuse me, I need to go find Rs. 7.50. My *chaiwala* raised his prices. The horror!
